Triggering Event: At 3 AM, during his graveyard shift patrol, he spots a familiar face from the neighborhood: Jimmy, a known troublemaker, laughing loudly with friends outside a closed bar. They've been harassing local businesses for months, and despite numerous warnings, they've never faced real consequences. The sight of them joking around ignites an ember of spite within him. He knows their antics have gone unpunished too long. Tonight, he decides, will be different.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, what the fuck is wrong with you people? I swear, that's like the third time this month we get a report about those fucking idiots from next door. How can they just keep getting away with it?! It's so infuriating. You know how many times I've had to deal with complaints about their shit? And now, here they are again, laughing their asses off at some stupid party. They're such idiots, acting like they own the place. What really gets me is that no one ever does anything about it. I'm so sick of seeing them walk into my house uninvited, drinking beer out of cans, and causing a ruckus. Those kids are nothing but trouble. And don't even get me started on the noise; it's like they think they own the damn street. I feel like I'm losing my mind, constantly dealing with these problems when no one else cares enough to stop them. It's so frustrating. They'll probably end up in jail soon enough, but until then, they continue to act like they're above the law. I wish there was something I could do to make it stop, but honestly, most nights I just want to pull over and hit them with my car. I hate how helpless I feel watching all this shit happen. But fuck, I just want to take action already! I can't stand how much more stress they put on me, especially since I'm working tonight. It's just so unfair

Triggering Event: He found her favorite book, worn and dog-eared, on their old shelf in the classroom. It had fallen behind some others, forgotten until now. He picked it up, feeling a pang of guilt for having overlooked it all this time.
Generated Assessment: You know what? I just can't help but feel like such an idiot. I've been searching for that one book everywhere, and it's just sitting there, right next to my other books. I mean, who puts something as important as that in the back? It's like they're trying to hide it from me. I could have sworn I saw it last week when we were setting up the shelves. But no, instead, it's here, quietly judging me for my lack of attention. I'm just so dumb; I really am. How could I have missed it? I must be blind, or worse, forgetful. You'd think someone with my level of responsibility would keep track of things better than this. And yet, here I am, still looking around for it, wasting time. What if I never find it again? The thought alone makes me want to cry. This is ridiculous. I need to snap out of it already. But every time I look at that book, I start thinking about how much I messed up by letting it slip through my fingers. My mind keeps going back to all the times I've lost track of things—my keys, my wallet, even my phone sometimes—and now I'm starting to wonder if I'm losing my memory too. This isn’t funny anymore. I feel like I’m spiraling into something deeper, maybe something more serious than just being careless. Maybe I'm slipping into something where you can't trust yourself

Triggering Event: Walking home from school, she pauses at their old tree. Its leaves whisper his name in the wind. She hadn't realized how dark it had become until she sees the lone figure of a child waiting at the bus stop. Alone, like her. The despair washes over her again, raw and relentless.
Generated Assessment: I can’t stand walking home from school anymore. I feel like I’m going to break down if I see him one more time. It’s been so long since we were friends that I almost forget what he looks like. His hair was always messy, but when I remember it now, I see the same messiness staring back at me. I hate how much he reminds me of my own brokenness. I have to force myself not to look at him because seeing him makes me realize I’ll never be whole again. He doesn’t even know why I skipped school today; he just waits for me by our old tree as usual. He is alone again, just like me. Why does everyone else get to live? Everyone else gets to go home with their families while I am left here alone, crying, and screaming silently. I wish I could scream loudly enough to drown out all the whispers of my past failures. Every day feels like another step closer to being completely broken. When will I finally be able to cry? Why did it have to happen at this place? This is where he used to hang out. This is where we would laugh together, sharing stories about our weekends. Now, I can’t help but think about how much fun we missed. How many times did we promise each other to meet up after school? What if we had met up then? Would things be different now? Maybe I wouldn’t be so broken, maybe I’d still hold onto hope. But

Triggering Event:
She returned home from work, her shoulders slumped beneath the weight of another monotonous day at the office. As she unlocked the front door, she heard the faint echo of the TV from the living room - a familiar, comforting hum that usually greeted her. Tonight, however, it was joined by an unfamiliar sound: laughter.

As she stepped into the room, she saw him there, his head thrown back, his eyes crinkling at the corners in a way that made his age show through the laughter lines. He wasn't alone; their daughter sat beside him on the couch, her tiny hands clutching at his arm as she too giggled along with whatever joke he'd just cracked.

The sight should have warmed her heart, but it only served to twist it further. She stood there for a moment, unnoticed, feeling like an outsider in her own home. This was supposed to be their family time, yet here they were, laughing without her, sharing jokes that she wasn't part of.

She cleared her throat loudly, causing them both to turn towards her with surprise. "I'm just going upstairs," she said quietly, turning away before either could respond. As she climbed the stairs, she felt a tear slip down her cheek. It was supposed to be different. They were supposed to be together in this. But lately, it felt like they were drifting apart, one joke at a time.
Generated Assessment: I've noticed that whenever I see couples laugh together, I get jealous. It's like my mind automatically assumes they're having more fun than me. Even if it is just a silly joke, it feels like they're excluding me from their inside humor. I try to make light conversations, but it always comes out forced. I guess I feel like I’m missing out when they share laughs together. Maybe I’ll try to lighten up myself someday. When I think about our family gatherings, especially holidays, I realize how much I used to enjoy being around everyone. However, now things seem so different. We don’t really talk anymore, and when we do, it’s awkward. My mom has been complaining about how stressed she is since I started working full-time. I know she wants us to spend quality time together, but every conversation feels strained. It’s hard to understand what she’s saying because of all the stress. I wish she would just relax, but she doesn’t seem to want to. When I see other families enjoying each other’s company, it makes me sad. I feel like I’ve lost touch with everything important. I can’t even remember what it’s like to truly connect with people. I guess I need to find new ways to deal with my emotions. # Conclusion This response reflects the cognitive distortion 'overgeneralization' because it takes a single case (a couple laughing) and exaggerates its significance, assuming it represents a pattern rather than an

Triggering Event: In the sterile silence of her office, she opened the letter from the medical board. The words blurred as she read: "Mandatory retirement at 65." She felt a hollow ache in her chest, like a patient's heartbeat growing fainter on her stethoscope. Another year, they said. But what difference would it make? Sixty-three years old and starting over again. The once vibrant room now seemed cold and bare, reflecting the emptiness she felt inside. She leaned back in her chair, closing her eyes, wishing for a miracle cure for this profound sense of hopelessness.
Generated Assessment: She was already depressed about leaving work. Now she had to deal with the fact that she has to leave work because she is too old. That’s awesome. Good luck with your new job, I’m sure you’ll have lots of fun. You know, just the thing to lift your spirits after being forced out of your career for being too old. I bet the interview process will be a real blast, especially when they ask you if you can still handle all those hours of standing on your feet and listening to people complain. Yeah, it won't be easy, but hey, who needs dignity when you're trying to get into something else? You know, I'm sure the new company will really appreciate your skills and experience. I mean, why bother hiring someone who's actually good at their job when you could hire some younger guy who doesn't know better? And think of the morale boost when everyone finds out that a bunch of middle-aged people are suddenly working under one boss instead of each other. It'll definitely be a lively place! I'm sure no one will miss the camaraderie of coworkers who have spent years building relationships and understanding each other. Who cares about that when you can have a bunch of new faces rushing around, pretending to be friends while secretly plotting against each other? I hear the pay isn't great either. Oh well, who needs money when you've got a chance to relive the excitement of starting over? Just imagine how fulfilling it must feel to go

Triggering Event: At 3 AM, he woke up suddenly, heart pounding like a drumroll in his chest. His breath caught as he fumbled for the bedside lamp, the darkness pressing against his eyes. The room was empty but for the ticking clock and the framed photos of stories past. He reached for his phone, hands shaking slightly, to check the time again - it was too early for the panic attacks to have started. But there they were, like old friends, ready to greet him with a familiar, icy grip.
Generated Assessment: It's ridiculous how I always get these kinds of panic attacks at exactly 3 AM. It’s as if my brain is wired to go off during this hour, no matter what else is happening around me. And even though I know logically that these aren’t about anything specific, somehow I still end up assuming every little thing has something to do with me personally. I remember one night where I thought someone had broken into our house because I could hear footsteps outside my bedroom door. Of course, it turned out to be just my roommate getting home late from work, but by then, my mind was already racing with worst-case scenarios. I’m starting to think that maybe this is just some kind of weird pattern—me waking up at 3 AM, feeling anxious, and expecting bad things to happen. It feels like my brain is programmed to freak out at this exact time, making me feel like it’s all about me when really it might just be some random noise or stress I’ve been carrying inside. But why does it keep happening? Is it something I ate before bed? Maybe I should try to calm down before sleep or something. Yeah, that sounds good. Or maybe I’ll just try to ignore it until morning. That’s probably better. I don’t need to wake up to another anxiety attack right now... Ugh, this is so stupid. Why does it always happen at 3 AM? Why can’t I just fall asleep peacefully like everyone else? This isn’t fair

Triggering Event: He's standing at his lab bench, microscope slides laid out neatly before him. The room is quiet save for the hum of equipment. Suddenly, he realizes he can't recall if he turned off the Bunsen burner in his office earlier. His heart pounds as he pictures the flames licking up the curtains, consuming his research, his career. He tries to rationalize, but panic surges; he has to check, now.
Generated Assessment: "Are you fucking kidding me? He's just sitting there, staring at those slides like nothing's wrong. I'm trying to get my shit together here, and they're just...just...fuckin' chillin'. They don't even know what's going on. Do they care that I might burn down the whole fucking lab? No. They just sit there, staring at their fucking slides. What are they even doing? I'm the one who has to deal with this, not them." He could've been more considerate. Maybe he was just too busy. But no, he had to be an asshole and leave us hanging like that. It doesn't matter how much work we put into our projects; it's all meaningless when he does whatever he wants. We have to pick up the slack because he's so fucking lazy. This isn't about being right or wrong. It's about how he acted, and that's all that matters. If he'd taken his responsibilities seriously, none of this would've happened. Instead, he gets to walk away with his precious slides while we struggle to salvage our own work. He probably thinks he's some kind of god, always getting away with shit because nobody can touch him. Well, let me tell you something, buddy: we're not gonna let that slide anymore." # Blaming # Blaming ## Feedback The response effectively demonstrates the cognitive distortion "Blaming". The author takes responsibility away from themselves by directing

Triggering Event: The clock on the kitchen wall ticked louder than usual, each second echoing through the silent apartment like a countdown. She stirred her coffee absently, staring at the phone that remained obstinately quiet. Another day had passed without a call from him. He was supposed to check in daily, but today was his fifth missed day. Her worry gnawed at her, each unanswered ring amplifying the fear that something was seriously wrong with their source deep undercover.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't shake off the feeling of impending doom as she stared blankly out the window. Every ticking moment felt like a countdown, each passing second echoing through her mind like a haunting reminder. It wasn't just the silence that unnerved her; it was the sense that time itself was working against her. Each minute felt like an eternity, every heartbeat a ticking bomb waiting to unleash its fury. Every missed call was a betrayal, a deliberate attempt to cut her off from the one person who could have changed everything. The more time passed, the more she became convinced that he was gone for good, that he'd slipped away forever. And yet, despite the mounting evidence, she refused to accept it. Instead, she clung to the hope that somehow, someway, he would find his way back to her, no matter how impossible it seemed. In her mind, there were only two possibilities: either he was alive, waiting patiently for the perfect moment to reappear, or he was dead, lost forever in some dark abyss. Anything less wouldn't be believable enough to ease her aching heart. If there was even a glimmer of doubt, she'd know—she'd feel it deep within her bones—that he was still out there, fighting for his life, waiting for the day when they might meet again. But until then, all she could do was wait, trapped in a world of perpetual uncertainty, where every passing hour felt like a lifetime. Time itself had become a

Triggering Event: Artist, late 20s, married, flips through social media, pausing on an image of an old friend holding a solo exhibition in Paris. She feels a familiar pang, envy biting into her like a wasp sting.
Generated Assessment: What's up with all these exhibitions? It's so hard to get noticed, especially when I'm working two jobs just to make ends meet. My art isn't even good enough to sell for more than $100, but everyone else is flaunting their masterpieces. And what's with all these young artists getting featured? I feel like it's rigged against me. The world should be full of opportunities, but instead, everything seems stacked against those who are already successful. I don't understand why people can just quit their day jobs to focus on their careers. Doesn't anyone care about the struggles of making ends meet? I have bills to pay and kids to feed. But no one cares about that; they're too busy talking about how much money they're making or how many galleries they've sold their work to. The world should be fair, where everyone has equal chances, but it feels like I'm constantly fighting against the system. I keep scrolling, and every post shows someone who's been accepted into some prestigious program or has made it big. Meanwhile, I see posts from friends who were rejected multiple times. It makes me wonder if there's something wrong with me. Maybe I shouldn’t be here, maybe I’m not meant for this life. Everyone else seems to know what they want and is doing well, while I struggle to make ends meet. What am I doing wrong? But then again, I think back to my own journey, and I realize things aren’t always easy

Triggering Event: He walked into their old bedroom, the scent of her perfume still lingering in the air after all these years. His hand trembled as he reached out to touch the dust-covered music box she'd loved so much. It played their song when wound up, but today it only clicked and spun in silence, much like his heart.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I can't even stand looking at that room anymore. The whole thing feels empty now, just like our relationship. I don’t know how many times I've broken down there, holding onto what's left of her. It’s like she's always with me, reminding me of what we had, of how far it's fallen. I remember how excited we were when they first moved in; everything was new, full of potential. But over time, it just got harder. The memories lingered, though—every little detail that made us who we are. I felt like I was losing myself, slowly becoming someone else. Every night, I'd try to find solace in the things we shared, but nothing seemed to fill the void. Even now, I feel like I’m living in two worlds. One is here, surrounded by the past, where every moment brings back painful memories. In another world, we're happy again, free from the weight of those moments. I guess you could say I'm trying to escape, but it's hard when they keep bringing it all back. It's like I'm trapped between two lives—one I thought was mine, but it turned out to be hers too—and one I wish I could live again. If only I could turn back time, I’d want to erase the pain, but I know that’s impossible. All I can do is hold on to the memories and hope someday I’ll move forward. Maybe someday,
